Graphical abstract In this review, recent advances and perspectives of MOFs and COFs in metal–air batteries were summarized, and some important issues as well as the recommended solutions in future are also described. Metal-air batteries (MABs) have attracted considerable attention as a novel energy technology that can alleviate the severe energy crisis and environmental pollution. Two primary processes, including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occur on the air cathode and dominate the battery performance during battery charging and discharging. Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and covalent–organic frameworks (COFs) emerge as promising cathode catalysts due to their structure and composition superiority. The unique characteristics of MOFs and COFs contribute to improved performance. This review mainly summarizes the recent applications of MOFs and COFs in a series of MABs, mainly including lithium- and zinc-air batteries. Additionally, some critical issues are emphasized regarding MOFs and COFs used in other MABs limited progress, their fabrication and alternatives to potential problems. Keywords Metal–organic frameworks Covalent–organic frameworks Li-air batteries Zn-air batteries Active sites 1 Introduction In today’s global society, the energy consumed to meet the needs of human beings is mainly derived from fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and natural gas [1–3]. Their massive consumption has accelerated the depletion of non-renewable resources resulting in severe energy shortage and environmental pollution [4–7]. Even though alternative power generation technologies like solar, wind, geothermal, and tidal have received increasing attention due to their “zero emissions” advantage, they still face intermittent power output [8]. Therefore, considerable efforts have been devoted to the exploration of novel energy storage technologies. In particular, rechargeable batteries such as metal-ion batteries (MIBs) [9–11] and metal-air batteries (MABs) [12,13] have been actively investigated and can be regarded as ideal energy storage and conversion systems to address intermittent power generation. Among the rechargeable batteries, MABs possess higher volumetric and gravimetric energy densities than MIBs, making them promising and advantageous technologies for future energy-related market requirements [14,15], particularly in the electric vehicle field where longer driving distances and faster charging and discharging are required. Generally, MBAs consist of a metal anode, an air cathode (such as oxygen and carbon dioxide), and a metal salt electrolyte. The air cathode is the central component and plays a key role in determining battery performance. The cathode releases and stores energy through oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) during discharging and charging, respectively. Traditional noble metal-based ORR or OER catalysts such as Pt/C, IrO2, and RuO2 no longer satisfy the requirements of large-scale use due to limitations imposed by their limited reserves, high price, and suboptimal stability [16]. Therefore, it is urgently necessary to pursue alternative approaches to achieve excellent electrocatalytic performance [17]. Ideally, the air cathode catalysts should possess the following virtues: (1) abundant catalytic components that provide accessible active sites to facilitate reaction kinetics and lower the battery overpotential during discharging and charging; (2) suitable pore structures to enhance the diffusion of air (e.g., oxygen and carbon dioxide) and avoid the deposition of discharge products on the electrode surface; (3) optimal adsorption abilities towards the gases to guarantee the high capacity of the battery. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), covalent–organic frameworks (COFs), and their composites with many unique characteristics show great potential for meeting these requirements when acting as OER or ORR or even bifunctional catalysts for MABs (Fig. 1 ) [18–22]. MOFs are porous hybrid materials constructed by inorganic metal ions/clusters and organic linkers through coordination interaction [23]. They are highly promising for use in many fields including gas storage and separation [24], proton conduction [25], catalysis [26], sensor [27], and energy storage and conversion [28–32], due to their advantages of diverse architecture, high specific surface area, regular and tunable pore structure as well as controllable chemical and functional properties. Recently, an intense research effort has been explored MOFs derivatives for MABs [33–36]. Even though much progress has been achieved, the MOF pyrolysis strategy tends to collapse the framework and destroy the regular pore structure, thereby contributing to the poor utilization of the inorganic/organic component. By comparison, the direct use of pristine MOFs as air cathode catalysts in MABs can effectively avoid the issues mentioned above. Similarly, COFs are porous polymers assembled by lightweight organic building blocks through stable covalent bonds to produce highly crosslinked networks with periodic skeletons and ordered pores [37–39]. Due to the designable chemical composition and skeleton, various COFs with different physicochemical properties and dimensions have been designed and synthesized in recent years [39–41]. They were then applied in energy storage and conversion [42,43], and in particular, they showed highly promising performance in rechargeable MIBs batteries rather than MABs [21,44–46]. Nevertheless, the designability of the organic linker is beneficial for the introduction of abundant active groups (such as CO, CN, NN), resulting in performance improvement of the COF-based air cathode catalysts, thereby making COF materials highly competitive to most of the porous catalysts, such as zeolites, MOFs, and polymers. Based on the structural and compositional features of MOFs and COFs, these two porous materials have been rapidly developed in the field of energy storage and conversion as cathode catalysts. To date, an enormous number of articles summarized the progress in the MOFs and COFs preparation and their applications in energy technique-related technologies, most notably for MIBs. However, extensive implementation of MOFs and COFs in the larger energy-related fields, particularly as air cathode of MABs, has remained elusive. In contrast, more attention has focused on the COFs and MOFs derivatives rather than on pristine ones. Fig. 2 summarizes some of the milestone breakthroughs works reported, which, to a certain extent, push the development of MOF- and COF-based materials in MABs. Herein, in this review, we will summarize and describe the cutting-edge use of MOFs and COFs in notable MAB applications, mainly including lithium- and zinc-air batteries (ZABs). Based on the representative examples listed above, some issues that must be confronted and the corresponding available solutions for the future application of MOFs and COFs in MABs will also be highlighted. 2 Application of MOFs in MABs 2.1 Li-air batteries In recent years, Li-air batteries including Li-O2 and Li-CO2 batteries, have received extensive attention as a class of novel energy storage systems [47,48]. Their extremely high theoretical energy density (e.g., 11,140 Wh kg−1 for Li-O2 batteries) compared with that of the state-of-the-art lithium-ion batteries pushes the energy density of a battery to the next level and highlights their great application potential. This makes Li-air batteries more suitable for meeting future market requirements, particularly for achieving longer driving distances for electric vehicles. As described above, the ORR and OER processes usually occur on air cathodes to realize the release and storage of energy during discharging and charging processes. Therefore, the catalysts of air cathodes are crucial for performance improvement. Unsurprisingly, the cathodes with prominent ORR or OER or even both ORR and OER activities may deliver outstanding battery performance. The emerging MOFs provide a new platform for developing novel cathode catalysts through targeted design [49–51]. Moreover, the unique advantages of MOFs, including high specific surface area, excellent gas enrichment capacity, and open metal/organic group sites, make them perfect for ideal air cathode catalysts to achieve excellent battery performance. Therefore, this section summarizes the recent progress of MOFs in Li-air batteries including Li-O2 and Li-CO2 batteries. Also, it discusses the existing issues and possible solving strategies for preparing new MOFs or modifying existing MOFs for use in MABs according to the earlier examples. 2.1.1 Li-O2 batteries Normally, the majority of Li-air batteries is often tested in a highly pure oxygen atmosphere and an organic electrolyte, thereby known as aprotic Li-O2 batteries. The relevant battery reaction is described by 2Li + O2 ↔ Li2O2; where O2 is reduced in the cathode to combine with Li+ ions and produce Li2O2 in a typical discharging process (ORR), while the accommodated Li2O2 product is decomposed to release O2 and Li+ ions in the charging process (OER) [8,52]. Rational selection of cathode catalysts is thus vital for obtaining excellent properties, and the inherent porous structure and electroactive component play key roles in obtaining improved battery performance. In 2014, Wu et al. reported the study of MOF materials in Li-O2 batteries [53]. Five typical MOFs with different specific surface areas and structural topologies (Mn-MOF-74, Mg-MOF-74, Co-MOF-74, HKUST-1, MOF-5) were chosen as cathode catalysts, and Mn-MOF-74 delivered the highest capacity of up to 9420 mAh g−1 at a current density of 50 mA g−1 (Fig. 3 a and b). This was ascribed to the abundantly accessible metal sites in the channels that bind the O2 molecules to facilitate the highly efficient reaction. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) results of the MOFs after the discharge and charge reactions reveal the structural stability of the cathode catalyst (Fig. 3c). However, severe capacity decay gradually occurred during six full cycles (Fig. 3d), indicating the incompletely reversible transformation of the Li2O2 product in the OER process. Subsequently, Kim et al. verified that bimetallic MnCo-MOF-74 obtained much higher discharge capacity exceeding 11,150 mAh g−1 at 200 mA g−1 coupled with a low overpotential of 1.26 V at a limited capacity of 1000 mAh g−1 and 44 cycles [54]. The Mn- and Co-metal clusters acted as active sites contributing to the high battery performance. Importantly, they investigated the formation and decomposition mechanisms of the Li2O2/LiOH discharge product and found that Mn sites promote the transformation of Li2O2 to LiOH. In contrast, Co sites can catalyze the decomposition of LiOH when the battery system contains a trace amount of water. Another typical example is the use of micro-nano structured Ni-based MOF (Ni(4,4′-bipy)(HBTC), 4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine; H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) as the cathode catalyst of Li-O2 batteries, reported by Hu et al. [55]. The targeted MOF catalyst delivered a high capacity of 9000 mAh g−1 and a good cycling stability of up to 170 cycles. The improved catalytic activity was credited to the effective utilization of the catalytic Ni atom and 3D continuous microchannels. The ex-situ XRD patterns verified the structural stability of MOF under discharging process and the formation of a single Li2O2 discharge product as well as its reversibility after charging. Interestingly, the MOF assembled soft package Li-O2 batteries exhibited a higher energy density of 537 Wh kg−1 than commercial Li-ion batteries of 130–180 Wh kg−1, indicating the great potential of MOFs in future energy-related technologies. The above examples show that the metal center and open porous structure are two staple factors determining the battery performance. The former catalyzes the reaction between Li and O2 to form and reversibly decompose Li2O2. At the same time, the latter provides separated and strictly confined spaces to induce the growth of Li2O2 toward a uniform morphology. Wang et al. introduced mesopore defects, unsaturated coordination environment, and Co species in primarily microporous Cu-BTC to facilitate the infiltration of mass and charge transfer and bifunctional catalytic activities, thus achieving a high discharge capacity of 7000 mAh g−1 [51]. Li et al. demonstrate the possibility of MOF cathode with abundant active organic groups in Li-O2 batteries [56]. They used ligand modification to strategically immobilize a redox-active 1,2,4,5-tetrazine (Tz) in MOF-74 framework to construct a Tz-functionalized MOF cathode (Tz-MOF-74), which ingeniously combines the advantages of the MOF structure with the redox-active moiety to facilitate the electrochemical reaction kinetics in the charge-discharge cycle of Li-O2 batteries (Fig. 4 a and b). As expected, the material showed improved sustainable capacity with a lower overpotential compared with otherwise similar batteries without the Tz moiety (Fig. 4c). In addition, cyclic voltammetry curves showed a much higher current density for Tz-MOF-74, verifying its enhanced electrocatalytic ORR and OER activities (Fig. 4d). Also, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results demonstrated the participation of the Tz moiety in the discharge-charge and the reversible formation and decomposition processes (Fig. 4e). This work further broadened the use of MOF-based cathodes in Li-O2 batteries with designability at a molecular level. Besides the inherently porous structure and unique catalytic sites provided by the metal and organic ligands, the crystal size and morphology can also influence the performance of MOF-based Li-O2 batteries. Downsizing the crystal size retains the inherent advantages of MOF and shortens the Li+ ion diffusion pathway and provides better accessibility of active sites for O2 molecules surface adsorption and reaction, thereby endowing MOFs with desired electrochemical performance. Yan et al. fabricated a series of Co-MOF-74 with different sizes and morphologies and found that the MOF with a nanofiber morphology and a smaller crystal diameter of 20 nm delivered the highest primary discharge capacity as high as 11,350 mAh g−1 superior to those of 1400 and 800 nm Co-MOF-74 but displayed poor cycling stability for only 8 cycles with a limited capacity of 1000 mAh g−1 (Fig. 5 a–c) [57]. Fang et al. used a Dy-BTC MOF with a mean crystal size of 60 nm in a Li-O2 battery. The electrochemical results verified that the nanosphere-based MOF cathode outperformed the bulk one, obtaining an improved discharge capacity of 7618 mAh g−1 at 50 mA g−1 and cycling stability for 76 cycles (Fig. 5d–f) compared with 2930 mAh g−1 and 26 cycles for the bulk-based cathode, respectively [58]. Additionally, ultrathin two-dimensional MOFs with diverse metal sources were also prepared and applied to the Li-O2 battery, and Mn-MOF with excellent ORR and OER activities achieved the superior discharge capacity of 9464 mAh g−1 and long-term cycling over 200 cycles [59]. In addition to the direct use of MOFs in the cathode, the intrinsically ordered porous structure of MOFs also makes them suitable for modifying separator/electrolyte systems that are considered critical components of Li-O2 batteries. Meanwhile, high structural quality and defect-free MOF layers are encouraged. By fully utilizing a tunable size of pore window toward MOFs, some inherent drawbacks causing poor sustainability of the battery, such as Li degradation and electron shuttling between the cathode and anode can be effectively prevented. Qiao et al. modified the Celgard separator with a Cu3(BTC)2 MOF to permit Li+ ions to pass through easily and block the redox mediator from reaching the anode due to the precise channel size design of the MOF. This efficiently restrains the Li degradation and self-redox on the anode, realizing a reduced charge potential, increased discharge capacity, and prolonged cyclability of 100 cycles at a high current density of 1000 mA g−1 with a limited capacity of 5000 mAh g−1, providing a possible strategy for designing the high-energy flexible pouch-type Li-O2 batteries [60]. Cao et al. synthesized a polydopamine-coated CAU-1-NH2 ([Al4(OH)2-(OCH3)4(H2N-BDC)3]·xH2O, H2N-BDC = aminoterephthalic acid) membrane to enhance the O2 permeability and hydrophobic behavior, thereby reducing the formation of byproducts and guaranteeing an excellent battery performance in real ambient atmosphere conditions [61]. 2.1.2 Li-CO2 batteries As discussed in Section 2.1.1, Li-O2 batteries show potential for next-generation energy storage and conversion technologies in future commercial applications, particularly in electric vehicles. However, in real ambient atmosphere conditions, various gases such as O2 and CO2 normally coexist and generate Li2CO3, when Li-O2 batteries are operated in air, inducing severe passivation of O2 electrodes [62]. On the other hand, human activity has led to increasing global accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere that causes a series of environment-related issues, such as climate anomalies, sea-level rise, and ocean storms [63]. Therefore, searching for novel energy storage technologies to efficiently transform CO2 into useful electrical energy is particularly significant, and this has motivated the development of Li-CO2 batteries. Li-CO2 batteries with the theoretical energy density of 1876 Wh kg−1 display a similar working principle to that of Li-O2 batteries [64]. The universal reaction mechanism for aprotic Li-CO2 electrochemistry is described using 4Li+ + 3CO2 + 4e− ↔ 2Li2CO3 + C. Where CO2 is reduced in the cathode, combine with Li+ ions to produce Li2CO3 and C in a typical discharging process (ORR), while the Li2CO3 and C products are reversibly decomposed to release CO2 and Li+ ions during the charging process (OER). Similarly, the cathode catalysts are also the core components determining performance. Takechi et al. studied the use of CO2 gas in batteries [65], while Liu et al. were the first to demonstrate the reversible cyclability of a Li-CO2 battery [66]. Generally, the key for obtaining high-performance CO2 electrodes lies in the effective and efficient conversion between CO2 and the inactive discharge product Li2CO3 that influences the discharge capacity and the charge potential, respectively. Traditional cathode catalysts such as carbonaceous materials [67], transition or precious metal compounds [68–72], and their composites [73,74], do not meet the future application requirements of Li-O2 batteries due to either poor CO2 capture (low energy capacity) or high cost. By comparison, the recent star MOF materials possessing highly ordered porous structure, accessible activity sites, and satisfactory CO2 capture capability may present a novel approach for the fabrication of high-performance Li-CO2 batteries in terms of substantial specific capacity, low overpotential, and good cyclability. In fact, the research on MOFs for Li-CO2 batteries is still in its infancy. Li et al. firstly explored MOF in a Li-CO2 battery system (Fig. 6 a). Eight porous MOFs were chosen as cathode catalysts to fix and convert CO2 [75]. As shown in Fig. 6(b), Mn(Ⅱ)-based MOFs with carboxylate linkers delivered a lower charge overpotential below 4.2 V compared with MOFs with other metal centers such as Co, Fe, Ni, and Cu, indicating better catalytic activity of Mn metal to activate the Li2CO3 discharge product during charging. Normally, the large pore size in MOF also plays a key role and enables the uptake of large amounts of CO2 molecules, thus guaranteeing a high capacity. As expected, the Mn2(dobdc) MOF (dobdc = 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) with a larger pore size shows a better CO2 adsorption property with the value of 143 cm3 g−1, and therefore delivers a much higher discharge capacity of up to 18,022 mAh g−1 at 50 mA g−1 compared with inorganic Mn(HCOO)2 and MnCO3 catalysts (Fig. 6c–e). Nevertheless, similar to MOFs in Li-O2 batteries, their development on Li-CO2 batteries is also early compared with their corresponding derivatives [49]. 2.1.3 Discussion on the design of MOF catalysts with excellent Li-air battery performance From the above-illustrated examples, the fundamental characteristics of MOFs, including their crystalline porous frameworks, adjustable metal centers, and abundant organic ligands, can be employed in the design and construction of cathode catalysts for Li-air batteries. The choice and design principle of MOFs with excellent battery performance theoretically should obey the following: (1) MOFs should possess high adsorption abilities towards CO2 and O2, which is the premise of high specific capacity of the battery; (2) large amounts of substantial activity sites from metals and organic linkers can be introduced in MOF frameworks to lower the battery overpotential and promote the ORR and OER reaction kinetics; (3) the unique merit of crystalline and porous structures in MOFs should be delicately predicted or designed, which guarantee the uniform distribution of metallic and non-metallic catalytic sites, confine other active species in the pore space to prevent their severe agglomeration, and induce the formation of discharge products with small size, thereby contributing to improved catalytic performance. All of them can collaboratively enhance the battery performance rather than the corresponding performance of every single component. Table 1 and Fig. 7 cover the current typical examples of MOFs used in Li-air batteries, which may reference the design and construction of MOFs with excellent battery performance. Most MOFs are classical ones, in which transition metals such as Co, Ni, Cu, and Mn, are chosen primarily as nodes while functional ligands with single- or multi-carboxyl groups are used as linkers. However, there are still some limitations for using MOFs in Li-air batteries, especially when most of them are too dependent on classical MOFs with poor conductivity and stability. Furthermore, exploration of promising MOF catalysts that meet the requirements mentioned above is lacking, which should receive more attention in the future. Considering the above advantages and drawbacks of MOFs, the targeted design and construction of novel MOF-based cathode catalysts with improved Li-air battery performance could be a promising direction for the future development of MABs. For Li-O2 batteries, a bifunctional catalyst is usually required to drive the formation and decomposition of the discharge product Li2O2. In this case, flexible MOFs could be constructed, where the active sites with different catalytic preferences in ORR and OER are more likely to be introduced. For Li-CO2 batteries, one of the feasible strategies is to introduce N-contained functional site groups (such as amino, imido) in carboxyl based-organic ligands to construct stable MOFs [23], in which the N site may effectively enhance the adsorption amount of CO2, thus improving the specific capacity of the battery. In addition, the construction of π-conjugated conductive MOFs or MOFs and conductive carbonaceous substrates (carbon nanotubes and graphene) composites is encouraged to enhance the charge transport property. 2.2 ZABs The current severe energy crisis and environmental pollution have stimulated novel electrochemical energy storage and conversion techniques [76–78]. Among these, lithium-ion batteries undoubtedly have achieved the broadest commercial success and have promoted the ongoing revolution in portable electronic devices and electric vehicles. However, their capacity and cyclability do not satisfy the ever-increasing requirements, particularly for long endurance. On the other hand, the discussed Li-air batteries possess ultrahigh theoretical energy density but suffer from inadequate life span and rate capability; therefore, their commercialization is hindered. In addition, the lithium resources shortage prevents their large-scale application. Furthermore, Li-based rechargeable batteries normally work in aprotic electrolytes that are a fire hazard. By comparison, aqueous ZABs have shown comparable efficiencies with multielectron redox couples, and benefit from abundant Zn resources, low Zn cost of below $100 kWh−1, and nontoxicity. Moreover, they have been reported to be suitable replacements for lithium batteries in large-scale applications because of their high rechargeability and practical potential [79–81]. Generally, ZABs are similar to Li-air batteries in that a porous air cathode, a Zn metal anode, and a separator are key components. However, they differ from Li-air batteries in that they use concentrated alkaline electrolytes. Both ORR and OER occur at the cathode during the discharge-charge cycle to realize multiple proton-coupled electron transfer and the overall electrochemical reaction is described by 2Zn + O2 ↔ 2ZnO (E aq = 1.65 V) [82]. Therefore, a cathode catalyst with excellent ORR and OER activities is vital for obtaining improved battery performance, and the materials used in Li-air batteries such as carbonaceous materials [83,84], transition metal compounds (e.g., oxides, perovskites, sulfides, hydroxides, single-atom catalysts) [80,85–88], noble metal [89], and their composites may also be suitable for ZABs (Fig. 8 ) [90]. However, their applications in ZABs are limited either by their scarcity or inferior bifunctionality or dissolution/aggregation in concentrated alkaline media during battery cycling [79,91]. Recently, MOFs have emerged as a novel type of unifunctional or bifunctional cathode catalysts for promoting the ORR and OER activities in ZABs, and some examples are listed in Table 2 and Fig. 10. The monodispersed metal cation centers or organic ligands act as catalytic sites, while the inherently ordered porous structure ensures the effective diffusion of O2, thereby jointly regulating the electrochemical behavior. Theoretically, the direct use of MOFs in ZABs should meet the following requirements: (1) excellent tolerance of water and alkaline media; (2) superior intrinsic activity and controllable mass/charge transfer; (3) hierarchically porous structure to guarantee the smooth permeation of electrolyte and O2 molecules accessibility. Due to their microporous structure and poor electrical conductivity, pure zeolite imidazole frameworks (ZIFs) series, a subfamily of MOFs, have shown unsatisfactory performance in Zn-air battery application until they are used in composites with inorganic components [92]. Xiong et al. encapsulated ZIF-67 in a hollow carbon sphere to construct a core-shell hybrid with abundant Co-N x active sites that deliver an ORR activity with a half-wave potential of 0.823 V that is superior to that of commercial Pt/C. The assembled ZABs show a high-power density of 120.2 mW cm−2 and good stability for 80 h [93]. In another report, ZIF-67 was combined with platinum (ZIF-67@Pt/CB) showed bifunctional electrocatalytic activity [94]. The power density and stability were improved to 150 mW cm−2 and 100 h, respectively. The synergy between the platinum nanoparticles and the Co-oxyhydroxide phase derived from ZIF-67 contributed to the superior activity. Moreover, some other ZIFs-based hybrids were also fabricated and delivered comparable electrocatalytic activities, e.g., Co-Zn ZIFs/Ni foam [92], and ZIF-67/Zn-GSMG (GSMG = guanosine supramolecular gel) [95]. Bimetallic ZIFs and their composites were also investigated as cathode catalysts. Xiao et al. integrated a bimetallic ZnCo-ZIF with conductive graphene oxide, contributing to superior ORR and OER activities, thereby improving performance when assembled in ZABs [96]. MOFs built by carboxylic acid-based linkers are typically used in ZAB cathodes [97]. Li et al. applied core–shell Co-MOF@Fe-MOF hybrid (ligand: 2-aminoterephthalic acid) as bifunctional OER and ORR catalysts in ZABs [98]. The oxyhydroxides species act as active centers to provide a positive open-circuit voltage and high-power density. However, the poor conductivity of MOF remains one of the major drawbacks preventing their use in ZABs. Therefore, conductive MOFs were constructed. Pan et al. demonstrated the success of Ru-doped π-type conjugated conductive MOFs (Ni5.7Ru0.3(HHTP)3(H2O) x ) as bifunctional OER and ORR catalysts in all-solid-state ZABs [99]. The ligands rather than the metals act as active sites and the introduction of Ru changes the coordination environment to improve the ORR activity. In addition, some conductive substrates were introduced to combine with MOFs, thereby effectively accelerating the mass and electron migration and enhancing the catalytic performance. In a typical study, stable, hydrophilic, and conductive MXenes (Ti3C2T x ) were chosen as a matrix to form a composite with a Co-BDC MOF (Fig. 9 a) [100]. Benefiting from the high surface area, porous structure, and Co active species, the as-formed composite delivered an excellent OER performance with a potential of 1.64 V at 10 mA cm−2 that is higher than that obtained with IrO2 (Fig. 9b). The Ti3C2T x -CoBDC and Pt-C-based ZABs also achieve a smaller voltage gap of 1.70 V than the standard IrO2 + Pt-C-based battery (Fig. 9c), indicating their potential for practical application. Inspired by this work, Zheng et al. fabricated bimetallic CoNi-MOF/conductive reduced graphene oxide composites as bifunctional electrocatalysts for rechargeable ZABs that exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activities with an open-circuit potential of 1.37 V, a peak power density of 97 mW cm−2, and stable cycling for 30 h [101]. To further improve the charge migration ability of MOFs, redox-active molecular linkers, such as metal porphyrin and metal phthalocyanine complexes, were introduced in well-defined MOF frameworks to catalyze the electrochemical ORR through M−N x and M−O x sites, thus highlighting their application in ZABs. Cichocka et al. rationalized the design and construction of a stable, accessible, and redox herringbone Zr-chain MOF catalyst by exploiting the strong affinity between metalloporphyrins and Zr (+4) cations (Fig. 11 a) [104]. The unique chain-based structure ensures the presence of close-packed and high-density Co cations active sites in the porphyrins, thus conferring the optimized PCN-226(Co) with enhanced ORR activity and ZAB performance with a half-wave potential of 0.75 V, a high-power density of 133 mW cm−2, and long-term stability of 550 charge-discharge cycles over 160 h (Fig. 11b–d). Zhong et al. developed a 2D conjugated MOF by using 2,3,9,10,16,17,23,24-octahydroxyphthalocyaninato copper (PcCu-(OH)8) as building units and cobalt bis(dihydroxy) complexes (Co-O4) as linkages [105]. The intrinsic Cu-N4 and Co-O4 with an unpaired electron in the antibonding orbital are the main catalytic active sites to afford satisfactory ORR activity. Meanwhile, their composites with carbon nanotubes were also fabricated delivering a better discharge performance and capacity than commercial Pt/C. Subsequently, some other MOF-based composites with abundant M−N4 and M−O4 active sites, such as Fe-phtalocyanine@carbon black [106] and UiO-66-NO2@CoCNT [107], were reported and investigated as cathode catalysts in ZABs, displaying comparable ORR activity and ZAB performance, thus showing good prospects for the future use MOF-based materials. Similar to previously discussed examples in the “Li-air batteries” section, these works also demonstrate the possibility of MOF-based catalysts in ZABs. The intrinsic crystalline porous structure, catalytic metal centers, and organic linkers benefit performance enhancement. Although great breakthroughs have been achieved, some deficiencies remain. As seen in Table 2, most of the reported MOFs just exhibit excellent ORR activities while their OER performance remains unknown. Also, the current exploratory MOF-based cathodes are limited to the classical ones with limited structure types. In practical ZABs, ORR and OER processes occur on the same electrode and together determine the battery performance, meaning that the selected catalysts should possess a bifunctional feature. Besides, ZAB tests are normally operated in highly concentrated alkaline/acidic electrolytes, and this requires excellent alkaline/acidic tolerance by the applied catalysts. In careful consideration, the targeted design strategies of MOFs with improved ZABs performance may reference the following points: (1) similar to Li-O2 batteries, various kinds of MOFs with distinct architecture and functional groups are also recommended to construct, which is convenient for the introduction of active sites with different catalytic preferences in ORR and OER; (2) the direct use of reported MOFs with high O2 accessibility and rich catalytic sites is another advisable choice, which could broaden and maximize the application value of MOF materials; (3) some active molecules, such as redox-active organometallic ferrocene and noble metal complexes, can be incorporated within thermochemically stable, highly porous MOFs to promote the battery performance synergistically. 3 Application of COFs in MABs 3.1 Li-air batteries Though much progress has been achieved for using MOF in Li-O2 batteries, some stringent requirements, especially excellent structural stability in different electrolytes, hamper its further development. COF materials are porous materials that preserve the MOFs’ merits, including adjustable pore and channel size and high surface area. Moreover, they also possess addition advantages in some aspects. For example, the structure of COFs is covalent bonds-based while MOFs are assembled by non-covalent interaction and weak intermolecular forces; this may equip COFs with high resistance to air and solvents than MOFs. Also, COFs are constructed from light elements such as carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen, indicating its much lower density than MOFs, hence improving battery performance. Regrettably, to date, COFs have attracted less attention than MOFs [108], probably due to the potential drawbacks, such as unpleasant electrical conductivity, poorer crystallinity than MOFs, and unexplored O2 adsorption ability. In terms of practical implementation, one of the outstanding abilities of COF material is CO2 capture [37], as verified by other examples shown in Table 3 . Diverse organic moieties with plentiful active groups (CO, CN) can be predesigned into the COF framework to guarantee efficient CO2 capture and activation [113]. Meanwhile, the reasonably designable and controllable channels and pore environment enable smooth and fast diffusion of Li ions and CO2 [114,115]. These multiple advantages indicate that COF materials will show extraordinary electrochemical performance when used as CO2-cathode catalysts. Li et al. demonstrated the first example of COF-based Li-CO2 batteries [109]. In their work, hydrazone/hydrazide-containing molecular units (Tf-DHzOPr, Tf = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxaldehyde, DHzOPr = 2,5-dipropoxyterephthalohydrazide) were chosen to construct a COF with high stability, open one-dimensional channels and skeletons, and good CO2 capture capability. The battery test results show that the as-designed COF catalyst delivers a discharge capacity of 9405 mAh g−1. Then, they hybridized the COF with carbon nanotubes decorated with catalytic and conductive Ru nanoparticles to improve the performance. Surprisingly, the as-obtained COF-based composite showed an ultrahigh initial discharge capacity up to 27,384 mAh g−1 at 200 mA g−1, a low cut-off overpotential of 1.24 V, and excellent rate and cycling capabilities. The synergistic effect among COF, Ru nanoparticles, and carbon nanotubes gave rise to a series of crucial processes, including CO2 adsorption and diffusion, and Li2CO3/C formation and decomposition, thereby achieving superior battery performance. Recently, Jiang et al. fabricated a MnO2 nanoparticle decorated COF nanosheet (MnO2/DQTP-COF, thickness of 1.87 nm) cathode by KMnO4-based chemical exfoliation strategy for Li-CO2 batteries with 2,6-diaminoanthraquinone (DQ) and 2,4,6-triformylphloroglucinol (TFP) were selected as the building units (Fig. 12 a–d) [111]. The as-designed MnO2/DQTP-COF hybrid delivers a high discharge capacity of 42,802 mAh g−1 at 200 mA g−1 with a voltage hysteresis of 1.46 V. The stability was well-maintained after 120 cycles at the high current density of 1000 mA g−1 with a fixed capacity of 1000 mAh g−1 (Fig. 12e). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations verified that quinone groups first acquire the electrons and convert them into an intermediate reduced state and then combine them with CO2 to form stable quinone-CO2 adducts with lower free energy than the direct process of CO2 → CO2 •−, thus facilitating the CO2 reduction reaction process to improve the Li-CO2 battery performance (Fig. 12f). They also merged a single metallic Mn sites and a versatile transfer channel into a porphyrin-based COF (TTCOF-Mn) to synergistically facilitate the reaction kinetics of Li-CO2 batteries [110]. Electron-donating tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) and tetrakis(4-aminophenyl)-porphinato manganese(II) (TAPP-Mn) were chosen as molecular building blocks. The abundant single metal Mn acts as an active site, and uniform microporous channels contribute to excellent performance with a low terminal potential of 1.07 V and long cycling stability at 300 mA g−1. DFT calculations revealed that the discharge reaction follows the TAPP-Mn → TAPP-Mn-CO2Li → Li2CO3 pathway. In addition, a graphene@COF composite was constructed through the Schiff base reaction to collaboratively enrich and confine CO2 in the nanospaces of micropores, facilitating both the electron and lithium-ion conduction, avoiding CO2 overconcentration and large-sized Li2CO3 formation, thereby leading to excellent battery performance [112]. Though great breakthroughs have been achieved for COF-based catalysts in Li-CO2 batteries, there are still some inevitable issues. The biggest challenge is that COF cannot reversibly decompose the Li2CO3/C discharge product, which requires introducing simple metallic substances or their compounds. This may prevent the further development of COF materials in the practical application of Li-CO2 batteries. In summary, MOF and COF materials have shown promising potential for applications in Li-O2 and Li-CO2 batteries comparable to state-of-the-art carbon materials, metal compounds, and their composites. The accessible catalytic sites and inherently tunable porous structures endow MOFs and COFs with an ultrahigh discharge-specific capacity. In addition, the crystalline size and morphology also influence the battery performance of MOFs and COFs. However, MOF and COF materials are still in the initial stage as cathode catalysts in Li-O2 and Li-CO2 batteries. This could be attributed to the inevitable disadvantages found in most MOF-/COF-based cathodes, such as unfavorable electrical conductivity and inadequate capability in decomposing emissions, thereby inducing inferior rate capability, high overpotential, unsatisfactory cycling stability (Fig. 13 ). Therefore, it is highly important to design and construct such materials targeted to meet the requirements of future applications. 3.2 ZABs Similar to Li-air batteries, ZABs performance is mainly influenced by the catalytic activities of cathode catalysts. Therefore, COFs are also promising candidates for ZABs due to the same pores and skeletons superiorities when used in Li-air batteries [116]. Typical examples and corresponding battery performance are listed in Table 4 . For instance, a 1D van der Waals heterostructure comprised of thienothiophene-pyrene COF and CNTs was synthesized and applied in ZABs [117]. Li et al. controllably constructed two crystalline thiophene-sulfur COFs with abundant bithiophene-S sites and used them in ZAB devices that delivered a power density of 164 mW cm−2 and were stable for 60 h [118]. On the other hand, considering the chemical behaviors and the vital role of metal porphyrin or phthalocyanine units in ORR activity improvement, these active sites were linked into COF materials via covalent bonds to demonstrate their potential in ZABs (Fig. 14 a) [119]. Carbon nanotubes were simultaneously interwoven into a flexible and robust CNT@POF hybrid film cathode as scaffolds to regulate morphology (Fig. 14b). When applied in both liquid and all-solid-state ZABs, the as-formed electrode displayed excellent electrocatalytic performance characteristics, such as a small voltage gap, outstanding stability, and high energy efficiency (Fig. 14c, d). In another work, Liu et al. exfoliated the bulk amorphous bimetallic ethynyl-linked phthalocyanine conjugated polymers into ultrathin nanosheets (Fe0.5Co0.5Pc-CP NSs), which were combined precisely with conductive graphene [120]. The as-fabricated hybrid showed an outstanding ORR activity with a half-wave potential of 0.927 V and was used in the ZAB device. The above examples clearly show that most of the COF materials were evaluated as unifunctional ORR catalysts that will inevitably require the use of commercial catalysts with OER activity (e.g., IrO2, RuO2) to assemble a ZAB. This still leaves the scarcity and high cost of Ir- and Ru-based catalysts unresolved. Therefore, the construction of COF-based catalysts with both OER and ORR electroactivities is particularly significant. Recently, Park et al. reported a pyridine-linked triazine COF (CoNP-PTCOF) modified with cobalt nanoparticles as an electrocatalyst with triangular morphology, abundant active sites, and hierarchical pores (Fig. 15 a–e) [121]. The introduced Co nanoparticles modified the electronic structure of PTCOF and enabled the adsorption and desorption of oxygen intermediates, thereby endowing the as-formed CoNP-PTCOF with bifunctional OER and ORR activities. As expected, the assembled ZABs delivered an excellent electrocatalytic performance obtaining power density and specific capacity comparable to those of a mixture of commercial Pt/C and RuO2 and with long-term durability (Fig. 15f). DFT calculations demonstrated that the active sites of CoNP-PTCOF originated from carbon atoms in the pyridine group (Fig. 15g). To summarize, the recent studies on ZABs, particularly those focused on the search for ORR and OER electrocatalysts, have increased exponentially, providing greater opportunities for investigating the COF materials and their ZAB-related electrocatalytic behaviors, thus extending their application in ZABs. The primary requirements for COF materials to enable their use as air cathodes in ZABs are summarized as follows. To allow the fast and smooth permeation of O2 gas and concentrated electrolyte during the discharging-charging cycle, COFs with tailored pores or channels and high structural stabilities are desirable. Combining conductive species with the frameworks solves poor conductivity by providing a highly efficient electron transfer pathway. The introduction of abundant active species (such as noble metals, transition metal oxides, and complexes) inside COF skeletons is favorable for satisfactory ORR and OER activities, thereby contributing to high ZAB performance. 4 Conclusions and perspectives Research into MOFs and COFs applications has seen explosive growth recently, particularly for energy-related technologies such as MABs. This is ascribed to their multiple advantageous features regarding the structures and components that facilitate electrocatalytic activities, such as abundant and accessible active sites for ORR and OER processes, tailored pores or channels for fast, efficient, and effective diffusion and permeation of gas molecules, and opportunities for functionalization with conductive substrates such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and MXenes. For the practical application of MOF and COF materials in MABs, numerous advances have been achieved and were reviewed here, particularly as cathode catalysts for Li-O2 batteries, Li-CO2 batteries, and ZABs. For the advancement of the field, we propose that more attention should be paid to the following aspects: (1) Even though thousands of MOFs and COFs have been reported, most show poor stabilities under harsh reaction conditions such as organic electrolyte or strong alkaline aqueous solution, which makes them more difficult to elucidate the electrochemical mechanism and limits their scale-up application in MABs. Therefore, the stability design of this kind of air cathode is of decisive significance for the overall performance of electrochemical devices. Typically, the adoption of azole-containing carboxylate linkers, multiple metal ions, and hydrophobic ligands can be used to improve its structural stability. At the same time, the development of “water-in-salt” electrolytes (WiSEs) also provides a platform for water-stable MOF and COF materials development. (2) The outstanding conductivity of catalysts is one of the prerequisites for their use as electrochemical components. Unfortunately, the poor conductivity and inadequate capability of MOFs and COFs to decompose their discharge products restrict their application in electrochemical devices such as MABs. Accordingly, the targeted design of MOF and COF materials with higher intrinsic conductivity and bifunctional ORR and OER features is considered an effective tactic for MABs performance improvement. The introduction of conjugated organic linkers, the auxiliary effect of conductive carbon materials/substrates such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and foam nickel, and the construction of p-type doping systems may be alternative strategies to improve the conductivity of the framework materials to a certain extent. (3) Whether in Li-air battery or ZAB systems, the current MOF and COF catalysts still confront inferior rate capability, high overpotential, and unsatisfied cycling stability, mainly resulting from poor OER activity. Therefore, a “structure-oriented” strategy to directionally prepare MOFs and COFs with unique ORR and OER performance is expected to be developed in the future for the continuous advancement of this kind of material. The optimization of OER performance can be achieved by introducing more 3d transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, and Mn) or noble metals (Ir and Ru), which can be used as active sites, or by using the strategy of directional defect construction to enrich the active sites and enhance the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. (4) For air cathodes, the electrochemical process involves a multielectron transfer reaction and the generation of several intermediate products. This may mask the real catalytic center and catalysis, further aggravating the uncorrelation between catalytic activity and catalyst properties, challenging to the targeted design of MOF and COF catalysts. Thus, in situ and in operando techniques such as Raman, XPS, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and extended X-ray absorption fine spectrum (EXAFS) effectively trace the intermediate states of electrochemical processes and provide the the electrocatalytic reaction mechanism. With the aid of theoretical calculation, these techniques may provide the avenue for the precise construction of MOF and COF catalysts. (5) Based on previous research, the development of new MABs devices by making full use of MOF and COF materials’ structure and compositional characteristics of will create more possibilities for the future energy market. For example, the recent development of N2 electroreduction reaction catalysts provides the possibility of a new type of Zn-N2 aqueous battery. Even though there are few reports on the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) of MOF and COF materials at present, they still have great long-term development potential. In addition, the full battery tests are highly encouraged to demonstrate the practical performance of catalysts if MABs are indicated as the targeted applications. (6) Based on similar working principles, it can be presumed that MOF and COF materials may be promising candidates for application in other MABs, such as sodium-air batteries, aluminum-air batteries, and magnesium-air batteries. However, considerable efforts have been made to adapt the MOF and COF derivatives developed for Li-air battery and ZAB systems for use in the above-mentioned batteries, particularly cathode catalysts. In contrast, the direct application of pristine MOFs and COFs in other MABs has received comparatively less attention. Thus, the continuous exploration of MOF- and COF-based cathode catalysts in MABs could be encouraged. Even though there are still many challenges in the application of MOFs and COFs to the air electrodes of MABs, the continuous research on these two types of materials and a deeper understanding of the reaction mechanism will provide increasing information to guide researchers to build better and more targeted materials, which are expected to promote large-scale industry application in the future. Ming Zhong obtained his MS degree (2014) from Northwest Normal University in Prof. Bitao Su’s group and PhD degree (2018) from Nankai University under the supervision of Prof. Xian-He Bu. He is now an assistant professor at Lanzhou University of Technology. His research interest focuses on MOFs/MOFs derived nanomaterials for energy storage. Ming Liu received his MS degree (2018) from China University of Petroleum (East China) with Prof. Jun Zhang. He is now a PhD student under the supervision of Prof. Xian-He Bu in Nankai University. His research focuses on the preparation of MOFs based electrocatalyst and its catalytic mechanism. Na Li obtained her MS degree in 2014 from Bohai University in the group of Prof. Xiuli Wang and PhD degree in 2018 from Nankai University under the supervision of Prof. Xian-He Bu. Then, she joined Prof. Bu’s group as a postdoctoral research associate at Nankai University. Her recent research focuses on the design and controlled synthesis of new porous materials for energy and environmental science. Xian–He Bu is a Cheung Kong Scholar Professor of Chemistry at Nankai University (from 2004). He obtained his BS and PhD degrees from Nankai University in 1986 and 1992 under the supervision of Prof. Rong-Ti Chen. Since 1995, he has been a full professor at Nankai University. He now serves as the dean of School of Material Science and Engineering, and a director of Tianjin Key Lab of Metal and Molecule-Based Material Chemistry. His current research focuses on the syntheses and applications of multifunctional coordination compounds, crystal engineering, magnetic materials, etc.

coredata.dc:description: Metal-air batteries (MABs) have attracted considerable attention as a novel energy technology that can alleviate the severe energy crisis and environmental pollution. Two primary processes, including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occur on the air cathode and dominate the battery performance during battery charging and discharging. Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and covalent–organic frameworks (COFs) emerge as promising cathode catalysts due to their structure and composition superiority. The unique characteristics of MOFs and COFs contribute to improved performance. This review mainly summarizes the recent applications of MOFs and COFs in a series of MABs, mainly including lithium- and zinc-air batteries. Additionally, some critical issues are emphasized regarding MOFs and COFs used in other MABs limited progress, their fabrication and alternatives to potential problems.
